Text: Spews out badwater during a Badtide.
An impenetrable obstacle that also blocks irrigation and contamination. It's difficult to demolish and can injure those who attempt it.

Info on rubble entity panel disintegration countdown progress bar

Header of the tutorial section that covers the basic concepts

Text: The game can be paused at any moment, helping you assess the situation and plan things out.
You can also increase game speed to reduce downtime while your beavers are working or sleeping.
First, let's have a look around the area.
If you want to check on your beavers up close, or get a wider view of the settlement, you can!

Beavers need a stable source of Logs. Duh.
                            
Using Science Points produced by your Inventor, unlock the Forester. Then build it in an area where you want to plant trees.

Use the Plant Trees and Bushes tool to plant some Birches. They grow quickly, making them a good choice in a fledgling settlement.
                                          
Similarly to crops, trees only grow on irrigated, green areas.
                                          
Remember to mark the planting areas for cutting.

Well done! You have laid the foundations for a great city but survival won't be easy.
                               
Build your first dam. Engineer new technologies. Grow your population and keep it alive.
                               
Succeed, and this barren land will turn into a beaver utopia. Fail, and you will share the fate of hoomanity.

Beavers do not reproduce unless there are empty housing slots available. Folktails need two adults and an empty slot for the magic to happen.
                                              
Tip: Beaver children are called kits.
Comment: The Tip is optional if there's no special name for beaver children in your language. If that's the case, remove this part.
If there's no special name for beaver children in your language use 'have a child'.

Text:
Two beavers are better than one! Houses improve your beavers' well-being and allow your Folktails population to grow.
                                      
Beavers automatically assign themselves to available housing slots.

Welcome to Timberborn! The tutorial will help you survive, build a beaver settlement, and bring life back to this wasteland.
                               
As you progress through the next steps, the tips will appear here.

It is time to start producing Planks!
                                    
Build a Lumber Mill directly next to the Water Wheel. You may also build it further away and connect it to the Water Wheel using Power Shafts.
                                    
Tip: Many buildings, such as Lumber Mills and Lodges, pass power to one another when placed wall to wall. No Power Shafts needed!

More advanced buildings require power, and beavers like their power to come from the river.
                                    
Place a Water Wheel in flowing water along the river bank.

Comment: Header of the tutorial section that covers the science
{0} stands for amount of Science Points accumulated, {1} stands for amount needed

Text:
Beavers are the engineers of the animal world. It's time to turn their lumberpunk ideas into reality.
                           
Build an Inventor to produce Science Points.

For now, let the Inventor work.
                                
Once you accumulate enough Science Points, we'll spend them to unlock more advanced buildings.

Comment: {0} stands for the name of the building to unlock

Text:
Many buildings have some built-in storage but it fills up quickly.
                               
Build a Large Pile to store more Logs.
                               
Each storage building holds a single good. You can set the stored good after selecting the building.
All liquids are stored in tanks. This includes the water we've been pumping.

Finally, let's prepare some storage for Berries. We should also get ready for the upcoming Carrot harvest.
                             
Food, just like many other boxed goods, is stored in warehouses.

In the long run, we need something more nutritious. Build a farmhouse to plant and harvest crops.
                                 
Like flags, a farmhouse has a limited range.
                                 
Tip: If you are running low on workers, you can pause some buildings. To do so, select a building and click the pause button.

In addition to water, beavers need food.
                                
Gatherers automatically gather Berries within the Gatherer Flag's range. You can see the range when placing the flag.
                                
Build a Gatherer Flag near some Blueberry Bushes.

Farmers do not start working until you tell them what and where to plant.
                                   
Use the Plant Crops tool to designate a Carrot field.
                                   
Crops need to be planted on irrigated, green land. Otherwise, plants will dry out and eventually die.

Beavers need water to survive.
                                 
Build a Water Pump to ensure continuous access to drinking water. Remember to connect the Pump to the District Center.

Well-being is a metric that shows how content a beaver is. It affects three attributes: working speed, movement speed, and lifespan.
                             
One of the main ways of increasing the well-being is through attractions. Attractions are buildings that beavers enter when not at work.
Select a beaver and check its needs

Well-being also increases around decorations. Beavers do not intentionally approach them, so place the decorations close to where your settlers hang out.
                          
A Shrub is the simplest decoration, and beavers appreciate every bit of greenery.

You can see the impact your actions have on your beavers.
                           
Select a beaver by clicking on it. In the panel, you can see its current well-being, attributes, and needs.
                           
Some needs can reach negative values and incur severe penalties or cause death.

For beavers, it's the entire society that counts. You can see your settlement's average well-being in the top left corner of your screen.
                                   
Click on it to see the fulfillment of all possible needs. There are many ways to make life in the wasteland more bearable.

Every building with an entrance must be connected to a District Center with a Path. When you select a building, you can see its entrance marked by an arrow.
                                  
Build Paths to connect the Lumberjack Flags to the District Center.

The Flags will not be built unless they are in the district's building range.
                                 
Select the District Center to see its building range. You can extend it by connecting Paths to the District Center's entrance.

Lumberjacks only cut trees in areas that you mark for cutting.
                         
The trees must be within a Lumberjack Flag's range. Select a flag to see its range.
                         
Use the Mark Tree Cutting Area tool now. Hold the mouse button to select multiple tiles at once.

Every beaver settlement needs Logs, and lots of them. Only lumberjacks cut trees. 
                                
Build Lumberjack Flags next to nearby trees.
